Text: Do you indeed speak justly, O rulers? Do you judge with equity, O sons of men?
Context: This introductory verse challenges the rulers' integrity, questioning whether their judgments are fair and just.

Text: No, in your hearts you devise injustices, and your hands mete out violence on the earth.
Context: The psalmist accuses the rulers of planning injustices and executing violence, pointing to corruption and moral failure in leadership.

Text: The wicked are estranged from the womb; the liars go astray from birth.
Context: A stark description of the innate nature of the wicked, emphasizing their propensity for deceit and wrongdoing.

Text: Their venom is like the venom of a serpent, like a deaf cobra that stops up its ears,
Context: The verse uses the metaphor of a venomous and unheeding snake to describe the dangerous and unresponsive nature of the wicked.

Text: which does not listen to the voice of charmers, though the cunning caster spells.
Context: The image of the unresponsive serpent continues, illustrating the wicked's resistance to wisdom and charm that might influence others to good.

Text: God, shatter their teeth in their mouths; O LORD, tear out the fangs of the lions!
Context: The psalmist invokes God's intervention against the wicked, using the imagery of breaking teeth and tearing out fangs as a plea for divine justice.

Text: May they vanish like water that flows away; when they draw the bow, may their arrows fall short.
Context: The psalmist prays for the complete and ineffectual demise of the wicked, that their efforts would fail to achieve their intended harm.

Text: May they be like a slug that dissolves into slime, like a stillborn child that never sees the sun.
Context: The desire for the wicked's destruction is expressed with vivid imagery, wishing their end to be as insignificant and unremarked as a dissolving slug or a stillborn child.

Text: Before your pots can feel the heat of thorns—whether green or dry—the wicked will be swept away.
Context: The psalmist predicts the sudden judgment upon the wicked, as abrupt as a pot being swept away before it can feel the heat.

Text: The righteous will rejoice when they see vengeance; they will wash their feet in the blood of the wicked.
Context: A portrayal of the righteous finding satisfaction in divine retribution, using a graphic image of cleansing in the wake of justice.

Text: Then men will say, "Surely there is a reward for the righteous! Surely there is a God who judges on earth!"
Context: The conclusion anticipates a reaffirmation of moral order, with people recognizing the reward for righteousness and divine judgment on earth.

column8: The final verse serves as an assuring climax where the justness of God's rule is acknowledged.
